Description: Lower part of a wooden seated figure: the figure was seated with his hands on his thighs, but everything above the waist has been lost. The execution of the work is rather rough; the thumb of the left hand is indicated, but the fingers are not; the right hand has been damaged. The feet end bluntly. At the level of the knees a hole has been bored through the figure from front to back, presumably to take a peg to secure the seated figure on a 'block' throne. The legs, feet, painted white to indicate a kilt.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr Harry Reginald Holland Hall
Curator's comments: This figure was probably once placed in a shrine aboard a model boat. It is associated with the hull of a model boat (1907,1015.11). The figure is similar to the seated figure on a model boat from the same excavations, now in the Musée d'Art et d'Histoire, Geneva, no. 4769 'bis'. The top of the head is flat and without wig. See E. Naville and H. R. Hall, 'The Eleventh Dynasty Temple at Dier el-Bahari', III (1913), p. 31 n. 1.
Bibliographic references: Glanville 1972 / Catalogue of Egyptian Antiquities in the British Museum II: Wooden Model Boats (6)
